question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
How many digits are in the whole-number representation of $10^{100}-9^{100}$?
ground_truth: Ten to the first power has two digits, $10^2$ has three digits, $10^3$ has four digits, and so on.  Therefore, $10^{100}$ has 101 digits.  The least number with $100$ digits is $10^{99}$, which is $10^{100}-10^{99}=10^{99}(10-1)=9\cdot 10^{99}$ less than $10^{100}$.  Since $9^{100}<9\cdot 10^{99}$, $10^{100}-9^{100}$ is between $10^{99}$ and $10^{100}$.  Therefore, $10^{100}-9^{100}$ has $\boxed{100}$ digits.

question:
$$10^{100}-9^{100}=(10-9)(10^{99}+10^{98}9+\cdots+10^29+10^1+1)$$

$$=(9+1)(10^{99}+10^{98}9+\cdots+10^29+10^1+1)$$

$$=10^{99}+10^{98}9+\cdots+10^29+10^1+1+10^{99}+10^{98}9+\cdots+10^29+10^1+1$$

$$=(10^{99}+10^{98}9+\cdots+10^29+10^1+1)+(10^{99}+10^{98}9+\cdots+10^29+10^1+1)$$

$$=10^{99}+10^{98}9+\cdots+10^29+10^1+1+10^{99}+10^{98}9+\cdots+10^29+10^1+1$$

$$=2\times(10^{99}+10^{98}9+\cdots+10^29+10^1+1)$$

$$=2\times(111\cdots111)$$

$$=222\cdots222$$

There are 100 digits in the whole-number representation of \(10^{100}-9^{100}\).
Final Answer: \boxed{100}. I hope it is correct.
There might be an error in the solution above because of lack of understanding of the question. Please correct the error, if any, and rewrite the solution. Only output the final solution \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
ground_truth: Ten to the first power has two digits, $10^2$ has three digits, $10^3$ has four digits, and so on.  Therefore, $10^{100}$ has 101 digits.  The least number with $100$ digits is $10^{99}$, which is $10^{100}-10^{99}=10^{99}(10-1)=9\cdot 10^{99}$ less than $10^{100}$.  Since $9^{100}<9\cdot 10^{99}$, $10^{100}-9^{100}$ is between $10^{99}$ and $10^{100}$.  Therefore, $10^{100}-9^{100}$ has $\boxed{100}$ digits.
